review:
1980 yen per month for a subscription.
Mediocre combat (It really needs a revamp).
The game is fine without a subscription if crafting isn't your thing, or if you don't mind using a mule to hold your mats. Using a mule is a big time waster and inefficient. The sub needs lowered in countries that have a weaker currency. 1500 yen is fine, nearly 2000 yen isn't. 
On the plus side, the game still looks great even after all these years. The stories are interesting and the exploration is better than average. The voice acting is top notch. 
I am torn on recommending this game, but ultimately I would say yes, if you plan to go subscription free. There is enough content in the base game to justify it's typically low price and some of the DLC and expansions are worth buying. Necromancer, Arcanist and Warden are good classes to pick up.

review:
OK.. SO...

This is one of my all time favourite games I have ever played.. Not just because it's in the Elder scrolls universe, but because it's one of the best MMO's ever made too!

 Almost infinite content, AMAZING community, excellent combat (Controversial I know) and the world just feels alive! There's always something to do! 

Join a guild (Mine is The GoldenBloodCoven  feel free to join us!) and the game gets even better! 

I used to have so much Gold that my counter was at 999,999,999 and I couldn't make any more money, so I started finding Noobs and giving away millions for new guild members... It got to the point that I created a fighting ring in my base and used to make Noobs fight to the death for a milly gold.. But no matter who won, they both got a milly each and I added them to our guild..

This actually led to me getting a Private message from one of the Zenimax Devs saying I looked like a Gold Pirate due to how much I was giving away, and they warned me of a perma ban if I didn't stop XD (I stopped) 

We ended up having such a lively guild that we hosted Trial nights every Saturday and had such a good time doing it! All in discord on voice, having a few beers and a great laugh!

I digress... Massively XD 

The last thing I want to tell you all is, the optional monthly sub, ESO+ is absolutely worth every penny... But if you buy the game you don't have to subscribe at all, it's yours to play for good. I definitely recommend the sub though!

This game is awesome.. Join the game, join my guild and lets go enjoy ourselves!

author: {'steamid': '76561199228200731', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 157, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1712316473}
review:
Got it while it was free and played for a few hours. It's decent, i love the first person and 3rd person view, i really hope they keep the scroll distance like that in ES6. The helmet details for other races is finally there, i also hope desperately they take that into the next elder scrolls. It reminds me of oblivion but with way better graphics. 

The UI is better than skyrim IMO, i hated how bland and depressing skyrim UI looked so this was a definite plus for me. Farming feels pretty good, i loved mining, it was really satisfying. I dread if they go back to how you mine in skyrim when the next elder scrolls comes out. The character creator is pretty awesome, they are definitely improving. I did expect characters to look a little ugly for a MMO but its pretty good for one. 

Combat and animations is kind of clunky, and the bow animation is really bad. No changes to it yet and i saw people ask for that nearly 9 years ago so i really don't have much confidence in stuff like that changing for the better. I just got turned off from seeing all the little QoL things they could have added like other MMO's do. 

I looked up how to get a torch and you have to buy it from the crown store, use an emote or find another source of light in some quest later. I just felt kind of defeated and didn't want to put time into the game anymore if i was going to keep finding stuff like this. I also wasn't much of a fan seeing classes and races locked behind paywalls, i feel like that should be going towards cosmetics, not in game activities and builds.

Overall i would give it a 6/10 for pulling it together a bit since the release. I just expected a lot more from it since i come from other MMO games that did better in quality of life (though not by much). To be fair i barely put in any time and this is a huge game so this rating is kind of pointless lol. Can't wait to see ES6 and play my favorite khajiits to death!

author: {'steamid': '76561198052850766', 'num_games_owned': 939, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 421, 'playtime_at_review': 421, 'last_played': 1712291936}
review:
Pros:

- Bastante gente
- No se siente mucho el lag
- Cada clase tiene 18 poderes (15 poderes con 2 versiones mejoradas de c/u, y 3 ults, lo mismo q los poderes)
- Poderes segun arma, las cuales al poder cambiar en combate dan mas versatilidad
- Habilidades pasivas por varios factores
- Bastante contenido, exploracion ok
- Gameplay interesante

Cons

- Mucho DLC
- 5 skills + 1 ult usables a la vez (podes cambiar de arma, lo que te permite usar +5 skills y +1 ult pero... realmente no quiero usar otro arma, asi que en caso de que uses el mismo tipo de arma 2 veces, obviamente 1 va a ser mejor que la otra, y ademas, es denso este sistema)
- Las clases, que son las que tienen versatilidad de poderes, son muy... meh. Encuentro mucho mas divertidos los poderes de arma pero a diferencia de los poderes de clase, son muy limitados.
- A veces hay npcs / guardias entre los enemigos y le das un golpe sin qrer y es super denso porque hay sistema de "crimen"

Podría darle una oportunidad más en el futuro jugandolo con amigos, pero a diferencia de otros MMO, jugar solo no es tan divertido

review:
After 80 hours of gameplay i can highly recommend this game to anyone that enjoys MMO's or loves the elder scrolls IP.

I played through the whole base game and the Necrom DLC in my game time, I got my character to CP level 200 through mostly chilled gameplay like story,base game and dungeons.

The only thing I can complain about is once you hit CP 160 thats end game as far as your gear score is concerned, you can't level your gear past 160 which I think is a big complaint from most of the community as you aren't really grinding for gear past 160 just certain gear sets with certain perks and traits you would want for your character build.

I will be playing more as I want to play the other DLC's but it can be discouraging knowing my gear score won't be getting much better than what I have already.

For the price of the game and for the ESO plus subscription it is definetly worth your time if your into this type of game.

review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Rating: ★★★★☆

Review:
Welcome to Tamriel, adventurer, where the epic saga of The Elder Scrolls comes to life in an expansive online world. The Elder Scrolls Online isn't just a game; it's a sprawling adventure that invites you to explore the rich lore and diverse landscapes of one of gaming's most beloved universes.

From the snow-capped peaks of Skyrim to the sun-drenched deserts of Hammerfell, the world of Tamriel is yours to explore, filled with ancient ruins, bustling cities, and hidden secrets waiting to be uncovered. Whether you're embarking on epic quests to save the world from destruction or simply wandering off the beaten path to discover hidden treasures, the sense of exploration and discovery is unmatched.

But what truly sets The Elder Scrolls Online apart is its focus on player choice and freedom. With multiple factions to join, diverse character classes to choose from, and a robust skill system that allows for endless customization, the possibilities for creating your own unique hero or villain are virtually limitless. Whether you prefer to wield a sword and shield as a stalwart knight, rain down destruction as a powerful sorcerer, or sneak through the shadows as a cunning rogue, the choice is yours.

And then there's the multiplayer experience, which adds an extra layer of excitement and camaraderie to the game. Whether you're teaming up with friends to tackle challenging dungeons and world bosses or facing off against other players in intense PvP battles, the sense of community and teamwork is both rewarding and exhilarating.

Of course, The Elder Scrolls Online isn't without its flaws. The combat may feel clunky at times, especially for those accustomed to more action-oriented MMOs, and the game's subscription model may deter some players. However, with regular updates and expansions that continue to improve and expand upon the game's content, The Elder Scrolls Online has evolved into a rich and engaging experience that's well worth the investment.

In summary, The Elder Scrolls Online offers a vast and immersive online world that's perfect for fans of the series and MMO enthusiasts alike. With its rich lore, diverse gameplay options, and vibrant community, it's a game that will keep you coming back for more as you embark on an epic adventure across the lands of Tamriel. So gather your allies, sharpen your weapons, and prepare to write your own legendary tale in The Elder Scrolls Online.

review:
First things first: I bought ESO directly from the homepage, so Steam doesn't show my real playtime.  But between my 3 characters I've played 1087 hours and I'm still playing it.
I will leave out most of the generals because you can read about them in those thousand other reviews.

What is the best way to describe this game? 
It's the MMORPG for solo players. There are many, many players still playing, which is kind of surprising for such an old game, but interacting with them is optional. Very optional. On the positive side, there is almost no kill stealing, because even hitting a MoB just once counts the kill for all players who did it. A few years ago they also added followers, which is an NPC that follows you around and helps you in fights and such. This made the need to interact with others even less (and it wasn't that much to begin with).
-It does most things right, but shines in none. I mean, it really has many concepts that are well thought out... but somehow  it feels mediocre in almost everything.
-It has a more or less classless system built around classes. Your class has 3 skill trees that are unique to it. But you also have many, and will get even more, other skill trees that aren't unique. This makes characters feel more and more like other characters the higher you level them. 
-It has the same lore, areas, and story flaws you know, love and hate from all the other Elder Scroll games - ok, except for creating your own self-healing uber-armageddon spells and spiffing fork of megadeath weapon smithing :) 
-It has kind of an action based combat system, but in most fights you just spam 2-3 skills and maybe parry or dodge once in a while, and since it came out for consoles you can even activate assisted targeting, which makes this combat system at least closer to a tab target combat system.
-It is the most open world MMORPG; because it scales everything to your level. While this can be seen as a strength (you can play with your friends who may be high level or noobs and not be afraid of dying all the time if you decide to start as a new player more or less immediately in the latest expansion), it is also it's biggest flaw. Because leveling up does not really make you stronger, it just gives you and your opponents more options. 
It has a unique pay-to-play system. If you don't care about crafting, you can play it forever, just buy the latest expansion and later DLC or newer expansions, if you like playing them. However, if you pay monthly, you get access to all content and a crafting bag able to hold infinite crafting materials. This bag is shared with your other characters.This may be done by just buying the base game and subscribing to ESO Plus for 10€/month instead of buying expansions +DLCs.

Would I recommend it? If you liked the Elderscroll games, definitely yes. This is the only Elderscroll game that wasn't made directly by HIM. And you know what? They made a lot of things better and it _really_ just works :)

review:
[b] There's something for everyone [/b] , sure the combat mechanics aren't super next gen, but the ui for fighting is similar to BDO, with a  take on a frontbar/backbar system.

[i] Skill Building/Gameplay. : [/i]
Once you hit level 50 you will have access to where the game 'really' starts: Champion Points. Champion points are universal across all level 50 characters, And you can slot each characters unique passive/active skills at will as they are each allocated to every character that reaches Champion Level. For Instance, I am around 892 as of writing, Starting a new character is not nearly as rough as in alternative games I could level to 50 within a week, maybe less from questing, which will then make me significantly stronger/potentially as strong as my main because we'd share champion points. (Skill points and craft points don't swap over naturally as they're char stats, but leveling a preferred weapon of choice on an alt isn't so hard, especially so once you hit 50 and have access to beneficial boons/passives per character.) 

PvE is pretty fleshed out, PvP has it's moments but outside of the primary Cyrodil/IC there's really not many options if any, feels, repetitious. Builds can be fun to toy w/though assuming you're not used to the only skills you've been using while you leveled to 50 for your first char. The blocking/Interrupt mechanics are a neat touch though too, instead of the typical dodge/roll to avoid and spam rolling it gives you an option to aggressively interrupt both raid bosses, and that pesky PvP healer you've caught. 


[i] Housing: [/i]  7.5/10. Housing allows individual furniture, and sometimes building/fabricating your own houses from crafted house panels/plots/wood/stone/bricks/ 45% of whatever you see is probably in a house somewhere as there are many zone based rewards from zone furnishing vendors upon quest/zone completion( (See also, Zone houses that you can buy for gold upon zone completion instead of alternatively buying them for crowns! My favorite is Stormhaven's Gardener)  not to mention antiquities.(Archaeology basically.) Gives you a fair limit, which I wish was a bit higher on some higher quality/valued crown houses, but so do most of the more casual players. Given the amount of alternate games I consistently play it seems, more fleshed out than the usual housing, perhaps close to FF with it being instance based. The crafting stations being available to use in your house is neat for when you have bounties too I suppose, Or have daily writs.

[i] Hardware notes: [/i]  Runs a bit warm on i9 CPU's, (Or at the least, mine.) Graphics are nice with a reasonable GPU and some settings (game) tweaks. DLSS runs odd, not sure why, would recommend toying about for a bit to achieve desired visual/performance outcomes. 

Overall the game rests at a hard 7/10 for me, Which is good. The housing and the guild based marketing systems are again, another take on something that's been around for a bit, but it does okay for the casual sub price. (Subscriptions give you access to all but immediately new DLC/Expansions slowly grandfather in for free over the year to 'everyone' through daily logins, Orsinium was free for 2 daily logins in March for instance. And also an unlimited space bag for any craft materials of which there are many more than you could realistically fit in your bag, plus double normal bag space and storage/bank space. )

review:
This is an amazing game with an even more amazing community. The learning curve when you first start can be REALLY daunting, but that is only because there is so much to do and to know in this game. However, you don't need to know it all right away, and there are plenty of getting started videos out there. Also, the Guild system in game is super nice. I was lucky enough to be invited to a Guild called the Grey Manes when I first started playing, and that made all the difference in the world. 
A word about builds. When you first start playing this game, don't worry about having the perfect min/max build. You won't need it for a long long time. Just learn the game, play in a style that suites you, in whatever race/class you want. While traditional roles apply to group content (Tank, Healer, Damage Dealer) you can do almost all of the over-world content with whatever build you choose. 
Also, this game is MASSIVE with A LOT of content. I currently have 3,657 hours in, and there is still a lot I have not done. 
There is a Crown Store "real money market place" but it is all cosmetic stuff; some of which you can get or earn in game. 
As far as the subscription, you don't need it to play the game, but I do recommend it for quality of life things like a craft bag, etc. However, I wouldn't cross that bridge to that decision until you try the game out a while, and see how it is for you. 
Dive in and enjoy. Hope to see you in Tamriel!!

[quote]
[h1]TES:Online - скарб для фаната, але симулятор скіпу діалогів[/h1]

[quote]
[h2]Передмова[/h2]
Перш за все хотілося б сказати, що дана рецензія планувалася після того, коли я пройду весь придбаний і набутий ігровий контент, але ось уже квітень 2024 року. Здається, рівно рік, як я придбав цю гру, награв 172 годин, яких насправді, мабуть, вистачило для того, щоб сформувати кілька слів про цю гру. 

Фанатом світу The Elder Scrolls я є з раннього дитинства, коли придбав у однокласника за 20 гривень диск із TES: Morrowind, в якому я насправді жив, а не проходив сюжет. На той час мій слабкий ПК не дозволяв мені вчасно почати грати в Oblivion чи Skyrim. Перше я досі не пройшов, бо після Скайриму йти в Облівіон якось не хочеться досі, хоч я його й придбав.  Аби вгамувати спрагу по більш детальному заглибленню не так в лор як в географію Тамріелю, я слідкував за великими модифікаціями для того ж Моровінду та Скайриму, над деякими з яких припиняли роботу автори, а інколи й продовжували через час. Тим не менш, коли я ще грав в ці ігри, більшості з цих модифікацій так я й не спробував, або їх не було. Я часто відмовляв собі в TES: Online, але одного разу придбав і тут почався мій "ВАУ"-ефект від колориту кожного регіону, кожної провінції, раси, та деяких "захмарних" світів. До цього я не грав в MMORPG, проте то був період, коли я взявся відкривати для себе щось нове. Нові жанри та стилі, які раніше ненавидів, не розумів чи не знав. Я ризикнув і в результаті....у мене двоякі враження...

[quote]
Нещодавно я слухав історію розвитку TES Online і був вражений, наскільки розробники цієї ММО обізнані в тому, що треба дослуховуватися до аудиторії і робити все для неї. Розробники TESO безумовно робили багато помилок, які згодом виправляли, надихаючись досвідом інших онлайн-проєктів - World of Warcraft та GTA Online. Наприклад, на початку в грі не планувалося введення режиму від першої особи, але робити гру класичною ММО було надто поганим рішенням в плані занурення в ігровий процес, тому гравцю самому дали обирати, який вид він хоче.  

Як я і сказав, TES: Online - гарна можливість побувати в будь-якому куточку Тамріелю.
Окрім масштабів ігрового світу мушу згадати, що в грі непогана кастомізація персонажа, де ви звичним чином зможете обирати расу, стать, кастомізувати зовнішній вигляд, обрати клас, ім'я та Альянс, що вже випадає недоліком гри, адже завадить вашому кооперативу з друзями. А в кооператив розробники вклали багато праці, адже він максимально комфортний, та мабуть в більшості задля нього гру і створено. Проте унікальність цієї ММО в тому, що ви цілком можете розважитись граючи соло, що стало моєю "ношею". Хоч я намагаюсь вибити максимально контенту, мені доводиться звертатись до гравців з інших країн за допомогою і ком'юніті тут допомагає. Воно до речі живе, як і сама гра, тож якщо ви вважаєте TESO мертвим проєктом - ви помиляєтесь. 

Загалом вам ніхто не заважає проходити квести: квести прологу, епілогу, доповнень. Їх тут десятки. Сотні. Кожен діалог озвучений із участю голівудських акторів. Проте мушу визнати, вони вкрай посередні, як і вибір в цих квестах і більшість з них крутяться навколо "віднеси, вбий, вкради, прослідкуй" і це настільки часто повторюється що разом із іншими активностями гри ти розумієш що ця гра - суцільна біганина із довгим заклікуванням мобів, а босів самотужки навіть не поборете скоріше за все, якщо вони світові а не сюжетні. А чи варто згадувати які пусті і одноманітні тут діалоги? Вони не несуть ніякого сенсу і я їх щоразу скіпав окрім декількох мабуть.
Моєю проблемою в грі стала прокачка. Вона була моєю проблемою і в Genshin Impact, через що у мене ніяк не виходило відчувати себе сильним, відчувати розвиток. Якісь добрі люди крафтили мені набори броні та зброї, щось я потім викидав і брав рандомне, але що так, що інакше я не отримав бажаного результату. Навіщо мені він? Мобів заклікувати справді втомився.  І разом із цією біганиною я зрозумів що не отримую ніяких емоцій від гри. Вивчати різноманіття природної краси регіонів Тамріелю класно, але те яким чином це подають - не всім сподобається. Але я й розумію, адже хоч нам і дали зернину The Elder Scrolls, проростає ж вона в ґрунті MMORPG, що виступає обмеженням більшості механік, процесів та подачі. Але обмеження...обмеження в прокачуванні деяких характеристик, обмеження на число декоративних тварин, обмеження інвертаря, обмеження  числа взятих квестів в кінці кінців! Жах...
[/quote]
[quote]
[h2]В результаті...[/h2]
Так як мені не вистачить обмеження символів, я перейду до висновку. Я придбав гру з ціллю перевести в щось увагу на тлі особистих проблем, самотності та життєвих негараздів. Але згодом я лише усвідомлював що я мрію допройти весь цей клятий контент і звільнити понад 100 гігабайтів зі свого ПК. Безумовно TES: Online - це родзинка жанру, є не класичною MMORPG, а досить полегшеною, але при цьому не зайде тим, хто не шарить в цьому жанрі. Вона гарно служить для вивчення світу і "пробігання" квестів, чи грі з друзями, але я буду тим унікумом, що не порадить гру для однієї особи. Так, в гру можна грати одному, але це не завжди буде комфортно. І контенту тут ну дуууже багато. 172 години для його проходження не вистачило. 
Звісно те, що недоліки гри - особливості жанру я не міг наважитись поставити грі "Не рекомендую", але я запитав себе "Чи придбав би я гру знову?" і я відповів ні. Як і не планував купувати будь які ще доповнення. Благо в грі багато бонусів, підписка не нав'язується, щодня роздають всілякі подарунки, в тому числі тварин, їздових і декоративних, та навіть інші DLC та сюжетні розділи. Я мовчу про те, що систему скілів тут зробили схожою на скіли в одиночних іграх серії, хоч тут вона працює інакше.

review:
An awesome experience if you're into the Elder Scrolls franchise! The game really digs into a lot of the lore you get ro hear and read about in previous games, and it definitely has the spirit of an Elder Scrolls game.

Gameplay is fun and well-optimized, you have a lot of freedom with types of characters and how to build their stats and abilities, and even the chance to reset them for in-game currency if you want a change. For an MMO, it's really single-player friendly. You can do most things on your own, especially if you utilize the NPC companions to help you along. Only certain group dungeons or World Boss fights really require being in a group. And while there are a lot of expansions, none of them are required, and really only restrict access to the specific zones and questlines. They even occasionally give away previous DLC.

Overall, a great experience and one I would recommend to fans of Elder Scrolls and MMO fans!

author: {'steamid': '76561198272495989', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 55308, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1757, 'playtime_at_review': 55248, 'last_played': 1712186832}
review:
Elder Scrolls Online is a standout title in the MMO genre. Its vast world is filled with captivating stories that truly shine, drawing players into its immersive universe. While some missions can feel repetitive, the diverse environments and characters keep the gameplay fresh and engaging.

The game's end-game content and PvP have a manageable learning curve, requiring some time to master builds but remaining accessible. Social features, particularly guilds, are a significant asset, providing valuable support and enhancing the overall experience.

One of the most impressive aspects is the high number of players encountered, which is notably higher than in many other MMOs, adding to the game's vibrant and lively atmosphere. Overall, Elder Scrolls Online is a fantastic game that I would highly recommend to any MMO enthusiast.

review:
По пунктам:

Сюжет - от 3 до 10/10. Разброс настолько огромен, ибо в одних локациях сюжетка не иронично прекрасна, но в других хочется разбить сценаристу лицо чем-то тяжёлым, потому что такой кринж выдумать - это талант.

Геймплей - 5/10. Вкусовщина. С одной стороны, довольно динамичный, всякие блоки, перекаты и прочие весёлые штуки в наличии. С другой, чтобы нормально дпсить в пве надо освоить "вивинг" (по сути, умение впихивать и обычную атаку с ЛКМ и скилл в одну секунду ГКД, ибо они у них разные), а про пвп в этой игре лучше тактично умолчать

Донат - настоятельно рекомендуется покупать пак сразу со всеми предыдущими главами. В длс спрятана тонна контента, многий из которого влияет на геймплей (та же археология из главы "Греймур" даёт доступ к мифическим артефактам, многие из которых довольно сильны и полезны, а "Саммерсет" откроет доступ к ремеслу ювелира, без которого не прокачать свою бижутерию), Также может оказаться полезной подписка, но не на ранних этапах - скорее, новичку она даже может мешать, так как вас будет закидывать в длс данжи, некоторые из которых даже на нормале могут оказаться неприятными из-за незнания механик и/или отсутствия дпса.
НО у вас есть возможность докупить многие предметы из внутриигрового донат-магазина за голду. Это будет дорого, а фарм может занять долгое время, но если вас это не пугает - вперёд. Я так скупил все длс и кучу косметики, к примеру.

Ну и в неоценимый плюс можно вписать то, что игра проходится почти вся в соло. И её даже желательно проходить в соло в той части, которая касается сюжета. С другой стороны, если вы фанат именно что групповых активностей... Ну, они тут есть, но на них сделан явно меньший акцент. Два данжа (на 4 игроков) + одно испытание (на 12 игроков) в год - не то чтобы много. 

Пвп - тактично умолчим. Просто скажу, что с последним патчем разработчики добавили сет, которым умельцы уже ваншотят всё живое не запариваясь. Но, к счастью, оно доступно только в специальной локации (Сиродиле и Имперском Городе), поэтому если вы не хотите пвп - достаточно просто избегать этих мест.

В целом, игру советую, иначе не сидел бы в ней с 2018 года, но нужно учитывать, что она обладает своими специфичными нюансами и может подойти далеко не всем

review:
Такий класний капелюшок на днях дали, просто 10 із 10. Звісно, рекомендую! Мій відгук куплений (капелюшком з пір'ячком)

А тепер без жартів.
Я багато років грала в варкрафт, тому постійно порівнюю тесо з вов. І на цьому фоні тесо виглядає набагато вигідніше. 

Переваги: 
+ халявочки щодня.
+ можна грати у будь який момент (в вов ти не лише купуєш доповнення, але й щомісяця платиш за підписку. тут цієї фігні немає і це круто)
+ кронний магазин - ай лав ю! мій гаманець - не дуже, але я особисто обожнюю!
+ нормальний онлайн.
+ можно одночасно тусити з різними гільдіями, ще й мати свою.
+ рибалка просто каєф.
+ будиночки прекрасні!
+ кулінарія дивно реалізована, але це смачно.
+ можна трайнути всі профи одночасно. не доведеться переживати муки вибору (в вов можна мати лише дві основні профи. додаткові не рахуємо)
+ красиві локації.
+ гарний редактор створення персонажа. 
+ за клас некроманта окрема цьомка розробникам.
+ завжди є чим зайнятися. 

Недоліки: 
- недружелюбна до новачків. можна дахом поїхати, доки розберешся як тут все працює.
- маунти криві, косі, дивні.
- пети взагалі не зрозуміло нахіба треба.
- мало зачісок для дівчаток.
- інколи настільки пінг скаче, що хочеться відкусити комусь вуха. з фпс те саме. 
- не подобається як реалізовані гільдії. від слова "зовсім". негодую як гм зі стажем з задротських часів вову.

Ось такий відгук від казуальної білочки, яка клала хвостика на хардкорну гру і любить атмосферність,  Тода Говарда та гарні історії!

Українців запрошую грати разом. Велкам в друзі, намутимо гільдію, будемо крутими шо ппц.

I could recommend the game if the technical issues would finally be resolved but it seems this has been an issue for years with no real fix from Zenimax.

review:
[b]ESO É O MELHOR MMORPG QUE EU JÁ JOGUEI, DITO ISSO:[/b]

The Elder Scrolls Online (ESO), lançado pela Bethesda Softworks em 2014, é um MMORPG ambientado no vasto universo de fantasia da franquia The Elder Scrolls. O jogo busca oferecer uma experiência online imersiva, permitindo aos jogadores explorar o mundo de Tamriel, realizar missões, participar de batalhas PvP e PvE, e desenvolver seus próprios personagens.

[b]Pontos fortes:[/b]

Imersão no universo de Elder Scrolls: ESO oferece aos jogadores a oportunidade de explorar um vasto mundo aberto ambientado no rico universo de Elder Scrolls. Desde as terras gélidas de Skyrim até as areias quentes de Hammerfell, cada região é ricamente detalhada, oferecendo uma variedade de paisagens, culturas e criaturas para descobrir.

Narrativa envolvente: A história de ESO é contada de maneira cativante, com missões bem escritas e personagens memoráveis que dão vida ao mundo de Tamriel. Os jogadores podem se envolver em uma variedade de arcos de história principais e secundários, explorando intrigas políticas, confrontando ameaças sobrenaturais e desvendando segredos antigos.

Flexibilidade de gameplay: ESO oferece uma variedade de estilos de jogo para atender a diferentes preferências. Os jogadores podem optar por se concentrar em missões PvE, participar de batalhas PvP emocionantes em Cyrodiil ou até mesmo se envolver em atividades de crafting e comércio para construir e personalizar seu próprio equipamento.

Suporte constante e atualizações regulares: A equipe de desenvolvimento continua a apoiar ESO com atualizações regulares de conteúdo, expansões de história e eventos sazonais. Isso mantém o jogo fresco e emocionante, oferecendo novas experiências aos jogadores regularmente e mantendo a comunidade envolvida.

[b]Pontos fracos:[/b]

Curva de aprendizado para novos jogadores: Assim como muitos MMORPGs, ESO pode apresentar uma curva de aprendizado íngreme para novos jogadores. A quantidade de sistemas de jogo, habilidades e mecânicas pode ser esmagadora para os recém-chegados, especialmente aqueles que não estão familiarizados com jogos do gênero.

Desempenho e problemas técnicos ocasionais: Alguns jogadores podem enfrentar problemas de desempenho, como quedas de framerate ou problemas de conexão, especialmente em áreas com grande concentração de jogadores. Embora a equipe de desenvolvimento trabalhe constantemente para resolver esses problemas, eles ainda podem ser uma fonte de frustração para alguns jogadores.

Microtransações e modelo de negócios: Embora ESO não seja um jogo pay-to-win, ele apresenta uma loja de itens onde os jogadores podem comprar itens cosméticos, montarias e outros itens utilizando moeda premium. Alguns jogadores podem se sentir incomodados com a presença dessas microtransações em um jogo que já requer uma compra inicial e uma assinatura mensal opcional.

[b]Recomendação:[/b]

The Elder Scrolls Online é altamente recomendado para os fãs da franquia Elder Scrolls que procuram uma experiência online imersiva e expansiva. Com sua narrativa envolvente, mundo vasto e flexibilidade de gameplay, o jogo oferece horas de diversão para jogadores de todos os estilos. No entanto, é importante estar ciente da curva de aprendizado para novos jogadores e dos possíveis problemas técnicos que podem surgir. Considerando o modelo de negócios do jogo, é importante avaliar se as microtransações afetam a sua experiência de jogo.

review:
This is maybe my favorite game of all time, so I am a little biased. I've been playing since launch on ps4 and recently swapped over to PC. If you are considering this game in 2024:


PROS:

The environments are dynamic and full of life (although way too many creatures in a space will want to kill you). Even a troll off in the middle of nowhere has its own small routine you can observe while fishing or loitering.

There are numerous different scavenger hunts and collectibles for every part of the map/DLC's. It's endless content for exploration and open world lovers.

The main story quests for the zones often end up being very engaging after the first 2-3 quests. They are also casually LGBTQ+ positive, which is nice, as an LGBTQ person to see.

The Dungeons and Dungeon finder are great. I don't have friends who play, so the dungeon finder has allowed me to play so much more content than I could on my own. This game includes many different player styles and activities. 

Housing and crafting systems are great for people who love a long and hard grind, harvesting materials and chancing upon recipes. I personally love this.

The Crown store has items available through Endeavor points, which makes the game fully accessible for aesthetics, mounts, and other bonus items for no additional real world money, other than the purchase price, if the player wishes. 

SO many aesthetic and armor customization options, through the collected gear, and the Crown Store. Almost no other player looks the same as each other.


Cons:

Not everything can be done solo (although there is SO MUCH solo playable content) which is more a heads up than a full con. To complete maps there are public dungeons and enemies marked by a skull which are not doable solo, or are available in the group finder. 

Crafting and housing are VERY GRINDY. Very. Grindy. Like, make this your day job if you want to do all the achievements for just this section alone. 

The radiant and side quests can get quite a bit repetitive, as can the different Alliance quests once you complete the Main Quests, and go for Cadwell’s Gold achievement. That being said, delves are not identical or even repeat.

Playing in 2024, there is so much content to catch up, it can feel very overwhelming, especially for new MMO players.

review:
ESO is a pretty nice alternative to a lot of other MMOs. Coming as a World of Warcraft player, my hopes were pretty high for this game to be good, and yes... it is very good. 

I already love the Elder Scrolls franchise, as Oblivion and Skyrim are two of my favorite Bethesda games, and I've always wanted to learn more about the lore. A lot of questions I had whilst playing Skyrim, for example, were answered by ESO, like: who the Ayleid were, the origin of the older factions (Daggerfall, Ebonheart, and Dominion), and even some better hints as to what happened to the Dwemer (though most is still unknown).

Gameplay is great! Very simple, easy to learn. And there is even a built in skill advisor to help you better familiarize yourself with your class and abilities. 

The fact I am not *required* to pay for a subscription to play is already a huuuuuuge win for me. ESO+ has its perks, I'm sure, but I don't really care all that much. Besides the excessive amount of microtransactions there are with the Crown Store, a lot of stuff they just give you. I can't tell you how many Experience scrolls I have on my main. Though I wish they would stop giving me poisons... nobody likes those.

I picked this game up, along with all the other expansions, for about $20 during the Spring Sale. Lots of stories to play through, and lots of grinding to do. I totally recommend giving this game a try if you either like the Elder Scrolls franchise, or just want to play a new (and better imo) MMO.

review: The game's pretty alright, but it has its fair share of flaws. First of all, most of its content is too easy. You can pretty much do every delve (solo dungeon) and even the usual group dungeons simply by spamming left click or a single spell and you don't even need to use the roll button or healing spells, most of the time.  I also wish there were more differences between skills like 'this skill does that much damage but it also gives you 10% critical damage for 30 seconds' and other simple stat increases/decreases and things like that. I think that wow does skill differentiation much better, but it's not tragic here. I do wish there was more d e p t h other than stat balancing. Even the champion point tree (after lvl 50 you do not get levels, but champion points which can be used for unlocking stars in 'constellations' which mostly give you % or flat stat increases) feels kinda boring as it doesn't give you fun, cool-looking skills or anything new really, just these boring increases. It would be pretty cool if it were like in wow's talent trees where every now and then you get a cool, really useful spell to use in your rotation. It would give you something to look forward to instead of a simple 'oh cool, with this champion point I can now have 0.1% more movement speed while out of combat.' Overall the experience is chill and pretty fun, the music is pretty, the zones look good and there are some really well written questlines and characters. I like the game as it's a pretty cozy, relaxing experience, but I feel like there could be so much more. There's so much unused potential.

review: Elder Scrolls Online: A non MMO RPG/ Fantasy players perspective. I know it sounds weird but hear me out... I have never tried an MMO RPG before, none of the classics that everyone has played, I always thought they wouldnt be for me and I still stand by them, I find them overwhelming and have a tough time getting into them. So based off that I never thought I would play this game at all, I have been an Elder Scrolls fan since I was a kid and since then have 100%/am 100%ing all the games. I have thousands of hours on Skyrim on PS3 and some on PC too, as well as this ive spent so long researching all the lore, I love the universe so much and because of this I thought id give this a try since it was the only ES game i havent tried. I thought I would play it for a few mins and never again but I was so wrong... I absolutely love this game, and it has since become my main game that I play all the time. There is so much to say about this game, firstly I really like how its kind of a blend between MMO RPG and skyrim, it makes it alot easier for someone like me to digest. The game has so many features yet it presents them in an easy to understand way. But at the same time there is always something to do! I love all the things you can undertake, of course the traditional questing, crafting etc. but other things like Antique scrying, House furnishing, and contantly added features makes the game super fun and always exciting! Additionally Im really enjoying the social aspects, The fact I can explore Tamriel with others and even if i play solo I can still be in a world full of players and seamlessly enjoy quests and exploration with them is awesome! It makes the world feel really alive and helps with the game feel really relaxing! On the topic of exploring tamriel, The world is absolutely breath taking. Its every Elder Scrolls players dream, to explore every area and them all having SUCH unique landscapes and architecture! Its abolutely incredible and you will find yourself just wondering around looking in awe! The gameplay itself is also incredible, the combat feels fun and fluid, mixed in with all the skills and customisation feels extremely fresh! This is how an RPG should be, play however you want and look however you want! I love all the different outfits, gear, mounts, pets, its all so creative! Additionally the quests are fun and the audio is a talking point for sure. ESO has really good voice acting, and just the sound design in general helps immerse you in this incredible world. I could talk about this game forever its absolutely incredible and features so many things. Overall if you havent tried this game, even if you arent a fan of MMOs, if you like the elder scrolls, this is a MUST play. you will not regret it!

I just cannot get passed the "why so many quests" part.
I have ignored this game since it came out and only now in 2024 i went for it after all, knowing that i might not enjoy the 80k quests that it will bombard u with.
the last 4 days i been trying to accept no new quest and finish the 25 i had on the list, btw, 25 is max quests u can have active at any time. and i have to admit i keep failing it. either i am not paying enough attention or every quest is giving me a sequel quest and they just wont let go. this alone is reason enough to quit and not look back and yet i keep coming back to it. but instead of playing, i quit it minutes after. so there may be something about the game i like, i guess but i cant figure out what it is. although most quests are short, like kill few guys or go pick this up or pick 3 mushrooms, it almost always ends up in doing more than that, and if it won't, the time it takes u to go there is a waste enough. not to mention, when u are there, u will get a sequel quest or find more enroute. so the circle is never broken.

if u hate doing quests all day do NOT buy this or play it even if it is free.
no way in hell i can recommend this game despite the love for the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082184164', 'num_games_owned': 1363, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 3523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2373, 'playtime_at_review': 2523, 'last_played': 1712414524}
review:
三四十个小时体验下来，给我一种在玩因为online所以妥协了单机设计的老滚5，npc没有了生动的互动，大多数任务就是到一个地方通马桶（主线做到冷港，其他支线乱做了好几个地方比如高岛），演出基本没有，地图设计割裂感严重。

当然，以上内容我并不非常在意，毕竟从可肝内容的数量上来讲更新了十年的ol肯定比不打mod的老滚5是多上不少的。但战斗系统是一脉相承的狗屎，加上延迟导致手感更差让我没绷住。打起怪来锁定弱到几乎没有，平A又不是自动施法，基本处于站桩长按鼠标（重击）的状态，然后穿插着放一轮没啥打击感的技能，有伤害提示的时候滚一滚。想象一下，一个任务流程最后出现的“关底boss”由于是ol必须给你一点强度上的压力，所以血量直接上到几万十几万，而此时我的龙骑，重击一下才4000+。于是漫长的原地站桩刮痧开始。期间有的boss还要给你招点小怪干扰一下，还要转转阶段，当刮了二十分钟终于剩百分之十血量的时候突然boss最后挣扎一波进新阶段给你暴毙了，你就等着重新再来一次二十分钟把，这坐牢的一样的战斗体验，在单机滚5里可能只会持续上个几分钟，更别提还能打战斗、动作方面的mod。但在ol，你就老老实实搁那刮把。我玩的龙骑，这就是最真实的战斗体验，其他职业不知道，可能法系会酷炫一点？

最后画面也是一脉相承的丑，不是无缝大地图，没有了整体感，大部分野外场景给我一种随便放了点建模的敷衍感。在别的网游里最让我忍不住充值的时装，在这游戏的基本没有购买冲动，百分之90的时装都给我一种是从npc建模上扒下来拿来卖（污染箱子爆率）的感觉，包括坐骑也是，带光污染、亮晶晶或者有特色的就没几个，还都得是开箱子出。买过一次特惠箱子，只能说，血亏

总投入=80多版本+一张59的月卡。内购开箱这种我个人没忍住冲动浪费的钱就不提了，和滚5打折只要50不到相比，无限推荐滚5。

author: {'steamid': '76561198881618715', 'num_games_owned': 39, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1702112567}
review:
Heya traveller!
God... ESO is a game, that's where we all agree!
But, let me begin with the pros:
PROS:
-You actually get to explore Tamriel! (A large part of it, if you want more, then pay!)
-The graphics are good for the time it came out
-You don't really have to pay for anything in the crown-shop, it's pretty much all cosmetic

CONS:
-The combat is absolute ass: Like, seriously, it doesn't have that nice feeling of, for example, Skyrim. Everything simply bounces off and does significantly less damage than in, again, Skyrim. (Even with completely unarmored or really lightly armored enemies)
-The story is pretty lame: I never really had any type of interest in the story here or in any of the side-quests. It all felt so boring.
-The dialogues are uninteresting: Have you ever felt like your life is boring? Then do not fret, for the dialogues of ESO have arrived! I almost fell asleep by how much and how untinteresting the dialogues were in this game.
-The quests are trash: It's pretty much mostly the same for every quest. Here, I'll list the three types of quests I fell over in my playtime here on Steam!; Walk from A to B; Go there, raid that dungeon and come back to me; Head to that location, kill XY/ kill XY amount of enemies there and return to me.
-Bethesda/Todd Howard have their stinky little corporate fingers in it: Let's be honest, we all hate Bethesda/Todd Howard. Now, that's not against the devs, but more against the marketing part of Bethesda. Of course, Bethesda is not on a level such as EA or Acitivision, but they're still near that!

Alright, traveller, I hope you got at least a bit reason to buy/not to buy this game. If you do and enjoy it, then Congrats! You have a vastly different taste than me! But if not... just buy Skyrim, Oblivion or Morrowind. All three of them are far better.

review:
The best Elder Scrolls and MMORPG experience Yet

The base game itself is amazing, the amount of content, from exploration, collect-a-thon, PVM/PVP, crafting, gathering, etc, the game has something for everyone to enjoy. It's DLCs add even more amazing content to the game, with new content and areas added semi-frequently. The amount of curated puzzles and actual voice acting for every interact-able NPC is really impressive, including player choices that make the gaming experience seem more tailored to the player. Player customization is unmatched, from variation in races, to each individual races designs, no two characters or NPCs will look the same. The amount of variation in NPCs and monsters makes the world feel more comfortable, without just vast fields of the same monster copy/pasted everywhere. Recent changes to how it is now, versus how it was at release have made it even better. Crafting and armor customization are immaculate, with an advanced override system with a large selection of armors, weapons, and dyes. Classes and skills allows playing in a range of styles, not locking you to the common MMORPG archetypes.  Overall, one of the last, best remaining MMORPGs that supports both solo and multiplayer gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198151452227', 'num_games_owned': 581, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1710997191}
review:
Fun with friends, but that is not much of a recommendation. Only serious Elder Scrolls fans will find lasting enjoyment from this MMO, seeing as how this game essentially weaponizes fan-service. I don't think Elder Scrolls lore buffs will find much enjoyment here, and someone who enjoys an Elder Scrolls game casually might have a good time here and there, but this is largely for people who breathe Elder Scrolls. Outside of that, there's nothing here that will make you a fan if you're not one already. 

The combat is pretty basic, even by MMO standards. On top of that, the story is pretty uninspired. Quests are certainly a fun distraction like every Elder Scrolls game, but also like every Elder Scrolls game, you'll eventually grow sick of side quests and try to find things on your own. The map is expansive, just begging for adventurers to uncover all its secrets, which is great. However, at that point you're playing a single player game, just with an MMO backdrop. Sure, the community is kind, I personally believe the Elder Scrolls fandom as a whole is pretty inviting and keeps things pretty lighthearted, but during my time in the game I didn't understand why I would want to party up and play with others, at least as far as the main and side quests are concerned.

Everyone in your party can complete the same quest, but not at the same time, it's pretty distracting. Additionally, the story is paper thin to start and there's not much there to grab your interest and hold onto it. Immersion is quite hard when you're inundated with advertisements for in-game currency, and quality of life improvements such as unlimited inventory space are a real-life purchase, not an unlock. 

The Elder Scrolls Online is, in essence, a decently fun multiplayer Elder Scrolls game that's sandwiched between questionable MMO quest design and scummy MMO monetization practices. I love TES games, personally I hold Morrowind in high regard as one of the best games ever made, but I can't quite recommend this game unless you're willing to put up with a bunch of nonsense getting between you and your fun. It's definitely a fun experience for fans if they're willing to put up with some of the genre's misgivings, however I feel cynical towards this game as a whole.

It feels like a pretty standard MMO that's wearing the carved-off flesh of a beloved open world RPG franchise that, at this point, is practically dead. Keep in mind: Skyrim released 13 years ago, and we're not even close to the release of Elder Scrolls VI. What this game has done, in function, is satisfy the fanbase's hunger for a new Elder Scrolls game. It does this by dancing, a not-too-original routine, and kicking the dead body behind the curtain in hopes that we don't realize this dancer is not all that great at what they're doing, and we'd much rather have that stand-up comedian come back on stage. After all, it's what we came for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039883392', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2388, 'last_played': 1711159803}
review:
If you are a big fan of the Elder Scrolls series and always wanted to play those games as a smooth co-op experience, then this might still be worth getting into. It really captures the feeling of playing an Elder Scrolls game... minus the sense of danger, adventure, and some of the charm.

The developer's emphasis on player choice is praiseworthy. I like the fluidity of leveling in the sense that you can go where you want and not hugely affect your XP gain. If you get distracted and randomly wander off to another continent to do a quest that looks cool, you aren't excessively punished for it. The fact that every class can fill any role reasonably well is also great. 

The problem gameplay-wise is the lack of challenge and the sheer sense of repetition in the quests. Once you realize how incredibly difficult it is to die while leveling, it's all over, and once that tension is gone the gameplay loop starts to show its cracks more and more. In order to allow players to go anywhere and do quests (or quest chains) in any order they want, it seems like they sanded out any possibility of a difficulty spike by making everything easy. The absence of challenge or mechanical depth in encounters mitigates some frustration for new players that may stumble into something excessively difficult early on and feel stuck, but the fact that you can go anywhere also means that if you were stuck on something and started to get annoyed you could just go somewhere else. Nah... just make it all easy. The closest thing I found to difficulty in leveling was trying to solo group events, but there's no reason to do that since it takes forever and the rewards aren't worth the effort.

In the same vein, they made stories easy to jump into and follow to the point where they all felt bland. This hit especially hard when accounting for the fact you are locked into most dialogues. In the main games you could often run around and loot a bit while listening to the narration which made boring bits of dialogue more tolerable. Most times when dialogue came up, I would skip through it as quickly as possible so I could get back to whatever I was doing, which also tended to feel bland and uninteresting, so I was pretty much screwed either way.

The thing that made me give up on this game was seeing the insanely expensive DLC and noting that many late-game builds require expensive DLC for some of their important supporting abilities. There are 5 year old DLC's that still cost $35, and because they are in the in-game shop, not the Steam store, it is far less likely they they will be discounted to a more reasonable price. I'm sure it happens, just not often enough and not at a significant enough discount for me care. It's hundreds of dollars if you want to do everything, including Elder Scrolls staples like the Thieves Guild and the Dark Brotherhood. Considering how gimped the questlines for the Morag Tong, the Fighter's Guild, and the Mage's Guild are, there no way that I'm paying $15-20 EACH to likely be disappointed with those quest lines. 

Hearing about this game for years as "one of the good MMOs", made me really want to try it. It still comes up in discussions when people talk about how dead the genre feels these days. Without that constant hype I would stopped far sooner.

 Frankly, if you or your friends aren't already into this game, I have no idea why you would bother playing once you get a taste of what it actually is.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993342803', 'num_games_owned': 53, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 13712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13712, 'last_played': 1658022376}
review:
My husband and I played this game looking for a "multiplayer Skyrim" experience and this was almost it. But not quite in the worst ways. Like most MMOs this game has features meant to keep you logging in regularly and keep you paying micro-transactions. Like a painfully small inventory. That's fine... we managed around it.

But omg this game is so easy. So, so easy. After learning the ropes we basically could do all the content without even touching the healing potions, and almost never dying. There are some harder group dungeons that we would tackle sometimes to get a bigger challenge, but it's not enough. This just isn't a challenging game at all. Which fine, I guess as an MMORPG you want to appeal to the widest possible audience... but eeesh you can dynamically scale difficulty based on how players are doing! Eventually we were going through the motions just to try and finish the main story line.

Also, we were trying to play this cooperatively and that is a bit of a mess. We ended up with a kind of pseudo-cooperative play. 

It's a shame about the easy difficulty because this is such a big world with so much to do and lots of potential. But it just kills any sense of accomplishment when the game is so easy. Even the big boss fights for major story moments were usually over in 30 seconds of mediocre effort. Really makes it feel very un-epic.

Not a game we'll return to, though maybe it's just because we aren't fans of the MMO format.

author: {'steamid': '76561198155015010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 977, 'last_played': 1711127847}
review:
Don't waste your time on this. Don't buy it even on sale.

First, the gameplay doesn't resemble the mainline Elder Scrolls games at all. Instead it plays like a Korean MMO where you mash your number keys to shoot pew pew powers at the enemy until they die. And there are exactly two types of quest: Kill something and Fetch something. 
All of that interspersed with copious amounts of woo-woo dialogue about the Mystical Dreamwaiver of Stonesnark and curing the poison Barfgrid the Mendacious, rebellious leader of the Hurlsnatchers put into King Rotund the Braggart's mead soup or whatever that you forgot about long ago and couldn't possibly care less about, all over the setting of a war among three stupid and impossible factions that don't make sense if one knows the first thing about ES lore and in a barely fleshed out time period no one knows anything or cares about, sorta like making a game about ASoIaF before the Andals set foot in Westeros or The Witcher before there were humans.

Second, and worse, you'll spend about half your time trying to get the game to login in the first place, because the game is full of ever new and ever more creative bugs, like having to accept the (27 different) Terms of Service and set your brightness every single time you try to log in, to simply not being able to enter at all because it won't recognize your account and will require you to type a confirmation code they're supposed to send to your email, but won't ever be sent (seriously, it won't even be in your spam folder, no matter how many times you retry the log in; it simply wasn't sent)(and apparently that's a known issue they haven't solved yet.) But ofc they have the time to make new tiny mission DLC they'll sell for $25 instead.

Also, the graphics are lazy as fuck. By the 10th NPC you see you'll notice that all, and I really mean ALL characters of each race have the exact same face with a different beard, and all females have the exact same face with a different hairstyle. All houses in the map look the exact same, and all all rooms have the same arrangement.
Nothing in the game seems to have weight, everything feels light and floaty, including your horse and your heavily armored character with a two handed sword. Feels jarring. 

Anyways, I think you get the picture by now. Bye. Don't get this. Mod your Skyrim instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198141467238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 36007, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 3543, 'playtime_at_review': 32464, 'last_played': 1712199065}
review:
The game play has remained the same for its entire life span. You will have 2 weapons both assigned a bar(where you can put abilities on and get access to use said abilities). And you fill your second bar with Dot/buff/debuff or anything that basically does things passively. Then fill up your first bar with each of single target/AoE spammable + one strong skill(like executioner, proc based ability... etc) and some more DoT/buff/debuff.

No matter what class, what weapon type you use it's essentially the same for all DPS roles. There's no mechanically distinguishable differences to be had in between different abilities. Buff yourself, debuff enemies, DoT, and spam the same ability over and over again for 8 years. And those buff/debuff/DoT all come in the same 'some number goes down, or that number goes up' type of numerical conditioners. Not mechanically unique/play style changing buff or debuff. 

If the game gave the players more accessible 'change class' system or at least 'additional class skill line update', or make weapon abilities relevant it would have been better, but no. The player base is so thick on 'wahhhhhh everybody will play the most meta build ever only and ONLY so just be stuck with one class forever or make another tune just discard your main character with all the zone quests done!!' attitude, I don't see any change coming to this system of a hell loop. These people don't understand RPG players like all the quest completed. Making a new character just to try out different play style isn't appealing at all. 

How is that, the older games like Skyrim or even Oblivion give the players more play styles within a single character? You might say 'oh, because ESO is an MMORPG, can't compare this to that of a single player RPG genre'... I'd say even WoW gives the players way more options. Usually 3 specializations for each class that give the players access to a quite different(entirely sometimes) play style within THE SAME ROLE. FFXIV? Class change anytime as long as you're not already in combat situation or in dungeon/raid/trial. ORSR? Literally free of being class locked.

If they are so hard pushing on one character one class system they should give each classes a new mechanic every big expansion or so. But no. It rarely ever happens.

The player base being so divided by PvP/PvE doesn't help this situation at all either. Any change to an ability carries over to the other content, making hell of a mess. Both parties care about balance, but it's hard to get the right balance for both PvP and PvE. And a change for one content can and will ruin the entire vibe/fun of the counter part.

A part of journey in this game especially anything story related like questing, voice acting, narration... etc are all decent, but you have no sense of getting stronger or any kind of character progression whatsoever, because the only thing that changes is the number. You don't get to have more complicated combat with new, stronger, better looking abilities with unique mechanics being unlocked related to the said abilities. Only the enemies get to have that.

author: {'steamid': '76561199333741969', 'num_games_owned': 57, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 5817, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 987, 'playtime_at_review': 4404, 'last_played': 1712326238}
review:
My friends gifted me this game to try it out. This review comes from the perspective of someone who NEVER touched an MMORPG besides 12 hours in total at World of Warcraft.

The game is incredibly fun with and without friends. The community is dedicated to almost everything that the game offers. You can easily find a PvP match with people that can help you learn the game, hop at some dungeons to earn rewards and xp, trade items to get incredibly more gold than you would get from selling from npc merchants or even find even smaller niche communities that are still fun to participate with!

I fell in love with the housing system the game offers. It is obviously something you will do in the late game once you made a good build for your character, because it needs lots of grinding for money, achievements and some other small quests to get most furniture, but the building is so enjoyable and accessible to do i couldn't keep myself away from it. It has simple controls but you can still make everything with the furniture you can get for your house. I made my own stone fencing for my garden by using the stone blocks i got from buying a house!

Besides that, it was kinda hard to get into at first because its my first actual mmorpg experience, which meant i had to learn a whole new game genre + what ESO has to offer by itself. To be honest, it wasn't that bad! I got into the hang of it quite easilly by getting guided by some kind strangers. 

Even at the first 10 minutes of my game i got a guy from turkey to help me defeat my first boss! The community mostly is pretty kind and it motivates you keep playing the game knowing you will have nice encounters like these.

The only bad thing i wanted to mention is how a good chunk of the good content is behind a dlc, but if you look on it from an another perspective the developers are really generous. Their dlcs are cheap and offer hours of content, while also give free dlcs at least once or twice per year from what i've seen! The campaign story for the dlc expansions is 100% better than the base game story, which from where you look at it from, you can see it as a good deal knowing you are getting something better to look on. Imagine you already liking the base game and then you realize your progression will lead to even more fun!

One last thing to mention is that you can get most items/furniture from dlcs by other players by just buying it/trading it from trader guilts. Saved me lots of time and money for the time being.

In conclusion i wanted to say it is an amazing game to start your journey on the mmorpg genre and just in general a well-worthwhile game for the long term. Hope the review is somewhat useful for whoever is considering getting the game!
